values.alignmentText: Seattle's evergreens, Puget Sound views, and strict stormwater rules keep neighborhoods lush, though industrial SoDo corridors still need air monitoring.
Climate models warn of more wildfire smoke and king tide flooding, yet Seattle remains safer than many U.S. metros if we plan for air-quality disruptions.
Cool summers and drizzly winters give long stretches of mild temps, though the grey season can feel endless without sunlight lamps.
Most of the year PM2.5 stays near 8 µg/m³, but August wildfire smoke from Eastern Washington can send AQI above 150, so we'd keep filters ready.
Seattle avoids hurricanes but lives with Cascadia earthquake risk, lahar evacuation routes, and occasional ice storms that can knock out power.
March–May highs climb from 12 °C (54 °F) to 18 °C (65 °F) with light rain and cherry blossoms, ideal for park outings in layers.
Typical highs stay near 24 °C (75 °F) with low humidity; occasional heat waves hit 32 °C (90 °F) but cool off overnight by the water.
September offers crisp 20 °C (68 °F) days before rain returns and highs dip toward 12 °C (54 °F) by November.
Winters hover around 2–8 °C (36–46 °F); snow is rare but wet cold and short daylight require cozy indoor plans.
Alki and Golden Gardens offer pebbly beaches with cold Puget Sound water—great for bonfires and tidepools rather than warm swims.
Atlantic and Pacific beaches range from chilly (12–18 °C) much of the year to bath-warm Gulf waters, so only southern coasts feel swimmable for long.
Ferries to the San Juans, day trips to Olympic National Park, and Mount Rainier hikes keep world-class scenery within two hours.
Seattle's 2024 minimum wage sits around $19/hour, supporting service workers better than most U.S. cities though housing still strains budgets.
Amazon, Microsoft, and Google routinely offer $170k–$220k total comp for senior engineers, keeping Trey and Sarah well above local medians.
Microsoft's Redmond campus anchors .NET demand, with AWS, Expedia, and healthcare systems hiring C# teams nonstop.
Seattle's startup scene and consultancies like Substantial still use Ruby, though opportunities are fewer than for JavaScript or cloud roles.
H-1B and similar visas exist but quotas, lotteries, and strict compliance make sponsorship unreliable for newcomers.
Despite inflation cycles, GDP growth, deep capital markets, and low unemployment keep the economy resilient for entrepreneurs.
West Coast tech embraces hybrid-first policies; it's easy to secure remote roles with occasional Seattle office visits.
Long hours, limited leave, and hustle culture clash with Sarah’s need for predictable downtime.
Nominal 40-hour weeks hide frequent unpaid overtime, especially in tech and startups.
There is no statutory paid vacation, leaving time off entirely to employer policy.
Two to three weeks is common after tenure, which remains modest compared with the family’s expectations.
Seattle balances a tech hustle with outdoorsy weekends; traffic can spike but neighborhoods like Ballard or West Seattle keep a calmer rhythm.
Schools run 08:55–15:25; big tech often expects 10:00–18:00 overlap with other time zones, so we'd rely on after-school STEM clubs or flexible hours.
Weekends revolve around kids’ sports, errands, and driving to activities, though vibrant city programming offers options.
Family culture varies widely—supportive services exist in some states but childcare and healthcare costs strain budgets.
Polyamory is legal but stigmatized; only progressive urban communities openly support non-monogamous families.
Expectations skew toward intensive, school-centric parenting with limited state support, though progressive enclaves offer flexibility.
Parks and museums are strong in big cities, yet car dependency and safety disparities complicate daily outings.
Public, charter, and private schools offer variety, but quality depends heavily on neighborhood wealth and district funding.
Quality programs exist but slots are scarce and costs rival college tuition, demanding long waitlists.
Washington's Working Connections Child Care subsidy helps lower-income families, but middle-income parents still face $1,500+ monthly daycare bills.
Visa holders qualify for subsidies only after residency proofs and income tests; expect to pay market rates while paperwork processes.
Citizens access free public schooling, yet district quality and funding inequality create big differences.
Most visas allow public school attendance, though undocumented families fear enforcement and some districts have residency hurdles.
Private and parochial schools are abundant but expensive, with elite institutions heavily waitlisted in major metros.
No national paid leave and limited child allowances; benefits depend on employer or state-level programs.
Temporary residents seldom qualify for state benefits and risk losing status if work is paused for caregiving.
Citizens enjoy broad access to community colleges and top universities, albeit with high tuition costs.
International students can enroll but face higher tuition and visa work limits, making persistence costly.
Gender norms are gradually balancing, yet cultural expectations around motherhood and career still surface, especially outside progressive metros.
Legal protections exist in many states, but anti-trans legislation and social pushback in others create an uneven landscape.
Federal civil rights and Title IX offer protections, though state abortion bans and trans healthcare restrictions erode consistency.
Women face pressures to juggle careers and caregiving, with norms varying sharply between progressive and conservative regions.
Expectations for men still lean toward stoicism and breadwinning, though urban areas embrace more flexible roles.
Startup energy, deep maker communities, and access to cutting-edge tech ecosystems continue to excite Trey.
English dominates in daily life and services, eliminating language barriers for the family.
Progressive policies thrive in coastal states, yet national politics remain polarized with conservative pushback.
Leftist politics exist in academic and activist circles but mainstream discourse remains skeptical of socialism.
Secular life is easy in cities, yet Bible Belt regions still expect church affiliation.
Attitudes toward sexuality are liberal in metros but conservative laws persist in other states.
Legal protections exist federally, yet state-level anti-LGBTQ legislation and social backlash make support uneven.
Friendliness varies; many neighborhoods are welcoming but mobility and individualism can hinder deep ties.
Strong national identity and belief in exceptionalism remain common.
Public opinion sees Canada as close and Mexico as a complex partner with migration tensions.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors respect US influence yet critique cultural dominance and policy swings.
Major cities run vibrant nightlife scenes with music, bars, and late dining, though smaller metros close early.
Casual dress norms dominate outside coastal fashion hubs, offering moderate style variety.
Urban centers follow global trends, while much of the country leans toward practical casualwear.
Gaming, outdoor sports, and maker hobbies are widespread, offering Trey and Sarah ample communities.
Robust convention circuit, specialty shops, and active clubs make tabletop communities easy to find.
Capitol Hill clubs, Belltown jazz bars, and the Seattle Symphony offer varied nightlife with a creative lean.
Platforms like Meetup and vibrant coworking hubs create steady social pipelines for remote workers.
Kayaking on Lake Union, skiing at Snoqualmie, and backpacking in the Cascades keep world-class nature minutes away.
Federal democracy with checks and balances remains, yet gerrymandering and minority rule structures frustrate progressives.
Religious rhetoric heavily influences policy debates, especially on reproductive and LGBTQ+ rights.
At-will employment, limited unions, and minimal paid leave fall short of the family’s expectations.
Market-oriented capitalism and individual responsibility dominate policy making.
Election denialism, voter suppression attempts, and institutional strain signal meaningful democratic risk.
Free-market norms prioritize business flexibility over social safety nets.
Institutions endure but polarization and sporadic unrest introduce uncertainty.
Partisan media ecosystems and algorithmic echo chambers skew information quality compared with the family’s desire for pluralism.
Narratives emphasize national exceptionalism and culture wars, making it hard to find calm, balanced reporting.
Progressive policies advance in blue states while conservative states curtail rights, leaving a mixed national picture.
Public trust remains low, matching Gallup surveys that show skepticism toward federal institutions.
Citizens rate corruption as moderate—campaign finance and lobbying raise concerns without daily bribery.
Legalized influence via lobbying and dark money overshadows petty corruption.
Median three-bedroom rents top $3,200 and bidding wars remain common in walkable neighborhoods like Capitol Hill or Queen Anne.
Violent crime is moderate but property crime and car break-ins are frequent; we'd invest in secure parking and home security.
Quality care is available but insurance complexity and high costs burden families even with employer plans.
Non-citizens face steep premiums, limited public coverage, and visa-linked insurance requirements.
Subsidies are limited and dependent on state programs, leaving most costs on families.
Default benefits include child tax credits and unpaid FMLA, which fall short of the supportive policies the family wants.
World-class universities contrast with uneven K-12 outcomes, so the family must select districts carefully.
Link light rail expansion, RapidRide buses, and water taxis support car-light living, though late-night coverage and Eastside links remain limited.
A lightly regulated capitalist system prioritizes markets over social protections.
Federal, state, and local layers add complexity, but withholding automation means payroll taxes are manageable.
A dual tech-income household faces combined federal and state rates around 25–30% depending on location.
Digital banking, credit access, and payment apps are robust, supporting entrepreneurial needs.
No state income tax helps, but high housing, childcare, and B&O taxes push Seattle budgets well above Midwestern levels.
Social Security and 401(k)s offer support but require sustained savings; healthcare costs in retirement remain high.
Non-citizens have limited access to public benefits and must rely on private savings and employer plans.
Diverse visa categories exist, but quotas, interviews, and sponsorship hurdles make immigration arduous for non-citizens.
As citizens, the family faces no entry barriers and can relocate freely within the country.
Citizenship grants permanent residency rights nationwide, though state benefits depend on domicile.
Citizenship is automatic for the family and their children, eliminating naturalization concerns.
Immediate relatives of citizens have streamlined sponsorship options, though backlogs affect extended family.
For citizens moves are immediate; sponsoring relatives involves fees and multi-year waits but predictable processes.
Legal compliance is straightforward for citizens, though regulated industries require diligent paperwork.
The U.S. tolerates dual citizenship, though obligations like taxes remain.
Visa holders must maintain employment, face travel restrictions, and manage complex paperwork to avoid status loss.
Microsoft, Bungie, Valve, and numerous VR startups hire year-round, making Seattle one of the strongest U.S. hubs for Trey's skills.
Home to 343 Industries, Bungie, Valve, and indie darlings like Campo Santo's partners, Seattle concentrates AAA and indie talent.
Meetups like IGDA chapters, GDC, and PAX West keep developer communities highly active.
Seattle Indies Expo, Global Game Jam, and access to Xbox and Amazon grant programs support founders despite high burn rates.
Gigabit fiber, electrified buses, and SEA's international flights keep infrastructure modern, though road maintenance lags in some neighborhoods.
